First some info. Doing an undergraduate course in geology here in University College Dublin. Entering 4th year now. My last year, 3rd year was hectic, generally 60 hour weeks, midterms and weekends taken up with fieldtrips. A stressful exam period, which I passed, only to be rewarded by a week long mapping training course in the west of Ireland, and then a 7 week mapping trip to Spain. Yes, seven summer weeks looking at rocks - joy - no summer for me. I am only back 2 weeks from this difficult, ball busting trip. So, all told a year of hard rockology with no real break.
 
 The issue is this, I have been considering deferring my 4th year to escape college for the year, and have the break I so desperately need - I am not sure I can do twenty straight months of rocks. My thesis (based on my work in Spain) will still have to be done, but I will effectively be deferring lectures, practicals and fieldtrips for a year. I would intend to get a job, hopefully in some thing relating to geology for the year, and also a bit of travelling, money is also an issue, as I have none of it now, and a year of earning could be very welcome. Means I will have spent a long time doing a 4 year degree
 
 Reasons to defer.
 Away from labs and other painful BS for a year
 Get money, have none currently.
 Travel at my leisure, with money earned
 Come back invigorated, ready to own those rocks next year
 Year of freedom
 
 Reasons against
 Forget load of stuff on return
 Could end up getting a pointless trivial job, if there are none available in my field - not much point in that
 Could easily end up just dosing
 Another year gone.
 
 Advice please, what should I do, similar experiences, travelling tips, job advice, anything!

post_info.post_title: My get out of college dilemma, go or no go?

If you can afford it, take a break, you can look at rocks for the rest of your life. Abuse your youth to do something you would never do once you got a house, a wife and, above all, a mortgage.
 
 I live (but not study) in a city that houses a life science-oriented university, and I've met boatloads of people who study for (usually) 3 years and then take a break to do something fun (trekking in South East Asia, for example) or something completely out of whack that somehow vaguely relates to their studies (Go to Australia to build a mushroom farm?)
 
 So if you can, just do it, just for the personal satisfaction when you can take your grandchild on your knee to tell them you went to Australia to build a mushroom farm when you were young!
 
 Just to be clear, I would suggest either a job for 9-10 months with a long holiday in the end, or the out of whack job at a weird location

Oooh, don't do it. It can be terribly difficult to get back into it. Terribly! Plus the weird school related stuff-taking a deferrment, student loans (have any? You'll have to start paying on them), Get your degree, then take your trips and have your vacation. No one says that the second you get your degree you'll have to get a "serious" job and sit down. If you think it might "look bad" for future employers to read you raised bees in South America, then find a rock-related job you enjoy. If you can't find one you enjoy, get out of the rock business. If you haven't enjoyed rockology the past year, and need a break, are you going to be able to last the next 30-40 years doing?
I agree with Bell. Get the degree done and then move on to the next things.
Finish while your study habits and life pattern are consistant. Getting back into the right frame of mind after a long break will be very difficult.

Dont take a break.
 
 It happened to me.
 
 Halfway through and never went back because I took a break.
 
 I have been very lucky to do as well as I did but I would have done better if I stayed in school.
 
 If any thing whatever job you have should be the something to try to get away from or reduce hours doing.
how'd it turn out? did you travel or hit the books?

I stayed, got on with the thesis (due in dec 13th) and will be finishing first semester soon.
 
 No idea what do after I graduate - possibly go for an internship in Tara mines here in Ireland - one of the largest Zinc producers in the world apparently

I stayed, got on with the thesis (due in dec 13th) and will be finishing first semester soon.
 
 No idea what do after I graduate - possibly go for an internship in Tara mines here in Ireland - one of the largest Zinc producers in the world apparently

 
 Good call. I realize that doesn't eliminate the current grind, but it sounds like your future prospects are excellent.
Well, i hope so, what with the metal prices being the way they are now, opportuities are looking up.

Well, i hope so, what with the metal prices being the way they are now, opportuities are looking up.

 
 Get the education completed. While there are no guarantees for anything other than death and taxes, it's one of those keys to life you don't want to be without. Unless, of course, manual or skilled labor for the next 40 or so years is your calling.

Funnily enough, the cause for the incredibly high zinc prices at the moment is the galvanising of chinese motorway crash barriers. But geology is a wide area, and as of yet I could decide to go into hazard volcanolgy, ores, peroleum or paleobiology. Dunno

STAY IN SCHOOL!
 
 It's just one more year, please stay in school.

Only do it if you can become employed in the field you're studying, geology perhaps an assistant to an environmental engineering firm, where you will remain incentivized (?) to return and the "time off" will enhance your overall resume for your field.
 
 As mentioned above, if you just stop for regular employment or because you are tired of it, you may find you never go back. That's what I did(n't) do. And as mentioned above, I've done okay, but would've done better had I stayed and finished my last year and a half.

GeorgeD nailed it, and thankfully, you nailed it too.
 
 Once you leave, you can never really go back. Get the degree finished, then all the doors will be open to you to walk through whenever you so desire.
 
 Keep on keepin' on.
 
 Waxy

Does it have to be a whole year break? When I was working on my undergrad I burned myself out one year by taking way too many credits at the same time. In fact I was getting my undergrad in Earth Science, minor in physics and chemistry. Science can be tough and I know what it's like to look at all those rocks. Anyway I took a 4 month break and that seemed to help a lot. I can't say I was the most effective person because honestly I was so exhausted. Before my short break I was taking 9 different courses. 4 of them were different lab classes that would require 3 hours of my time when they were in session and the other 5 courses were a combo of science and education courses. I would get about 2 to 3 hours of sleep every night and spent the rest of my time either in class, in the library doing research, or at home doing homework. I moved back home with my parents after that for the 4 months and opted to become their personal maid. I had no energy to even go out and get a job and deal with stress from a real boss. At least my parents paid me to be their maid and cook. After my 4 months of being a maid/cook I decided to go back to school. I felt so much better and I learned to not jam pack my schedule. So all in all a break would be beneficial, but you might not need to take a year off. However one thing you might want to do is go backpacking in Australia. You can get a working visa that will allow you to work at different jobs about 3 to 4 months at a time. It is an extremely popular thing to do, so you most likely would be able to find a job to do, unfortunately it probably wouldn't be in your field.
you should get your degree first ,, then do anything you want in life..

title: 4Forums.com Political Debates and Polls -  My get out of college dilemma, go or no go?
